nodes.label: Event

properties.description: The taxation crisis began with the Stamp Act of 1765, which colonial leaders viewed as a violation of their rights as Englishmen, triggering widespread discontent and a rallying cry for 'no taxation without representation.'

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: Colonial leaders, unified by the principle of 'no taxation without representation,' organized effective resistance against British policies through the formation of committees of correspondence and the implementation of economic boycotts.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: George Washington's strategic decision to carefully avoid major decisive battles while concurrently building and preserving colonial military capacity enabled the Continental Army to effectively survive British campaigns throughout the extended conflict.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: A crucial alliance with France was successfully negotiated by diplomatic leaders like Benjamin Franklin, which subsequently provided indispensable military and financial support to the American cause during the Revolutionary War.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: The American Revolution of 1776 culminated in the successful achievement of colonial independence from British rule, fundamentally driven by effective revolutionary leadership that mobilized a unified opposition.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: The emergence of effective revolutionary leadership, exemplified by figures like George Washington, John Adams, and Thomas Jefferson, was the fundamental driver that successfully transformed scattered colonial grievances into a unified independence movement and sustained the American Revolution for eight years.

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: Economic grievances or external pressures alone were sufficient and primary drivers of the American Revolution, capable of accounting for the organizational capacity and sustained effort required to achieve colonial independence.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: The text explicitly states that the American Revolution was fundamentally driven by the emergence of effective revolutionary leadership, directly linking leadership to the core cause.
properties.source: Revolutionary Leadership and Colonial Independence text
properties.source_text_quote: The American Revolution of 1776 was fundamentally driven by the emergence of effective revolutionary leadership that successfully mobilized colonial opposition to British taxation policies.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: The text argues that effective leadership coordination was a necessary condition for achieving sufficient unity among the diverse colonial population for the revolution to succeed, implying that without it, unity would not have occurred.
properties.source: Revolutionary Leadership and Colonial Independence text
properties.source_text_quote: The evidence suggests that without effective leadership coordination, the diverse colonial population would not have achieved unity sufficient for successful revolution.

nodes.label: Evidence

properties.description: The text directly refutes alternative explanations that solely focus on economic grievances or external pressures, stating they fail to account for the necessary organizational capacity, thereby reinforcing the central role of leadership as a doubly decisive factor.
properties.source: Revolutionary Leadership and Colonial Independence text
properties.source_text_quote: Alternative explanations focusing solely on economic grievances or external pressures fail to account for the organizational capacity required to sustain the eight-year conflict.
